media_attachments.description:
Abstract

There is increasing concern that the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) may collapse this century with a disrupting societal impact on large parts of the world. Preliminary estimates of the probability of such an AMOC collapse have so far been based on conceptual models and statistical analyses of proxy data. Here, we provide observationally based estimates of such probabilities from reanalysis data. We first identify optimal observation regions of an AMOC collapse from a recent global climate model simulation. Salinity data near the southern boundary of the Atlantic turn out to be optimal to provide estimates of the time of the AMOC collapse in this model. Based on the reanalysis products, we next determine probability density functions of the AMOC collapse time. The collapse time is estimated between 2037-2064 (10-90% CI) with a mean of 2050 and the probability of an AMOC collapse before the year 2050 is estimated to be 59±17%.

keywords: 

AMOC Collapse, Early Warning Signals, Tipping Time

card.title: Probability Estimates of a 21st Century AMOC Collapse

descendants.content:
@_noelamac_ @parents4future
Realistically, no government in Europe can reliably do anything to *prevent* it at this point, so every government of northern Europe should be taking active steps to mitigate the problems is is DEFINITELY going to cause.

Transport infrastructure, city planning, power grid, home insulation, everything.

24 years out is BARELY enough time to get this done.

It's not possible to exaggerate this, and it's not going away if we ignore it.

descendants.content: @petealexharris @parents4future If we think governments aren’t capable of doing anything to prevent it, or at least try, which means actually accelerating GHG emission reductions; how can we then expect them to perform the even more difficult and practically impossible task of adapting to the effects of AMOC collapse, i.e. irreversible and gradual slowdown of the AMOC current?

descendants.content:
@_noelamac_ @petealexharris @parents4future They won't. The only collective action they could achieve in that timescale to hit any target would be to start WW3, which they do seem to be working on.
That and maybe panic level upper atmosphere seeding games which might be even worse.

Either way several billion people are going to die, and this looks like the only way society will manage to significantly reduces the carbon footprint 8(

descendants.content:
@_noelamac_ @parents4future

Don't get me wrong, of course they should act to drastically reduce carbon emissions, because there's more than the AMOC to worry about.

I'm saying even supposing they do, and the rest of the world helps too, the chance to turn it around before disruption of the AMOC was probably years ago.

We aren't going to see a lot of cliff-edge tipping points coming at us, but this one, there's no excuse not to plan for it.

descendants.content: @_noelamac_ @parents4future thanks for the refrence, I know the impacts from a postgrad in the 90s but that was theory, the modelling is so much more advanced now. Given the timeline biodiversity loss gets overrun by the climate drivers. Hmm we've got some serious work to do and fast, very very fast. It's two sides of the same problem, have been trying to slow the biodiversity loss to slow climate change and has become slowing climate change to prevent extensive biodiversity loss. The acceleration in 30 years is beyond sobering

@_noelamac_ @parents4future

I bet it is going to happen on january 19th 2038 at 03:14:08 UTC.

descendants.content: @_noelamac_ @parents4future just adding a link to describe what AMOC actually is for those like me that dont know. But summarising Wikipedia it is an ocean current that if it drops will cause Europe to get cooler. Complex models say it probably won’t stop. Simpler models, presumably like the one used here think it should stop around 2057.
@demallien @parents4future IMO the article linked in the starting post sufficiently explains what AMOC is.
